topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny tees up the episode around major shifts in SEO due to AI answers, and introduces Eli Schwartz’s background and focus on AI’s impact on search.

topics.title: Why AI forces a rethink of SEO
topics.summary: Eli explains how classic SEO tactics stayed the same for years, but AI is forcing leaders to reconsider what SEO traffic means and how it drives business value.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor reads for Pendo (product experience platform) and Brave Search (private independent search with AI answers).

topics.title: How Google AI Overviews came to be
topics.summary: Eli walks through ChatGPT’s disruption, Google’s response (Bard, SGE/AI Overviews), and the key constraints: ads monetization, liability, and plagiarism concerns.

topics.title: Top-of-funnel discovery gets swallowed by AI
topics.summary: They discuss how AI answers change search behavior: not just pushing links down, but making generic discovery queries less valuable for publishers and SEO-driven content.

topics.title: Early impact: not apocalypse yet, but coming
topics.summary: Eli explains why traffic impacts haven’t fully shown up yet (limited rollout, rollbacks, algorithm updates masking effects) and which categories will be hit hardest.

topics.title: Structured vs unstructured answers and SEO disruption
topics.summary: Using Lenny’s Hanukkah site example, Eli distinguishes structured data answers from AI’s new ability to summarize unstructured content—where the real disruption happens.

topics.title: Top vs mid vs bottom funnel search examples
topics.summary: Eli gives concrete examples (podcasting tools, CRM) showing AI will handle broad comparison queries, while SEO opportunity shifts to mid/bottom-funnel intent like pricing and capability.

topics.title: What to do now: treat SEO as product
topics.summary: Eli argues SEO is a product problem, not a marketing afterthought: product and marketing must collaborate to build experiences for self-discovery users and match real intent.

topics.title: Zapier case study: programmatic integration pages
topics.summary: Eli describes early Zapier SEO: users searched for connecting tools (e.g., Gmail + Salesforce), so Zapier built scalable pages showcasing integrations, creating a discovery flywheel.

topics.title: Tinder case study: local intent and loneliness problem
topics.summary: Eli shares how Tinder approached SEO by mapping the real job-to-be-done (solving loneliness in a new city) and creating city-level pages; AI Overviews don’t replace that mid-funnel need.

topics.title: Practical steps to start SEO in AI era
topics.summary: Eli outlines a 3-step approach: deeply understand the user, decide what asset/product to create (often programmatic), and build it with real product resources (design, eng, research).

topics.title: When SEO is a bad fit for SaaS
topics.summary: They discuss why many SaaS companies struggle with SEO: unclear search intent, long decision cycles, high friction, and committee-based purchasing that doesn’t convert from content.

topics.title: How to evaluate SEO ROI and tradeoffs
topics.summary: Eli breaks down SEO’s true costs (people, tools, engineering, content) and urges comparing ROI vs other channels; examples include SurveyMonkey’s freemium fit and a gardening SaaS better served by trade shows.
